did.abstract: The James G. Riggs Papers collection contains materials collected by members of SUNY Oswego about the third principal of the Oswego Normal School from 1913 to 1933. During his tenure as principal James Riggs expanded the industrial arts program and opened Park Hall, added more land to the current college location, and guided the school through World War 1, the outbreak of Influenza Epidemic of 1919, and the onset of the Great Depression.

bioghist.p: James G. Riggs was born in Dexter, New York on May 21, 1861. His parents were Edwin Starr Riggs and Cynthia A. Hardy Riggs. He graduated from Potsdam Normal School. He received a Bachelor of Arts degree in 1888 and later a Master of Arts degree from Amherst College.

From 1891 - 1893 he was the principal of Watertown (New York) High School. He then was superintendent of schools in Plattsburg, New York for seven years. From there he taught at a private school in Dobbs Ferry for five years. In 1905 he became superintendent of schools in Orange, New Jersey until his move to Oswego, New York in 1911 to become the third principal of Oswego Normal School. He remained at Oswego until his retirement in 1933

Among his interests and activities are the following:
President of the New York State Historical Society. President of the Oswego Historical Society. President of the District Historical Society. Honorary degree of Doctor of Pedagogy from Albany Teachers' College. Member of the Board of Visitors of Rome State School. Elder of Grace Presbyterian Church, Oswego, New York. Member of the Fortnightly Club, Oswego, New York. Member of Lake Placid Club. Member of Theta Delta Chi fraternity. Member of University Travel Study Club, 225 South State Street, Syracuse, New York.

After his retirement, Dr. & Mrs. Riggs (May Jones Riggs) went on a world tour. Detailed letters were published in the Oswego Palladium-Times. (Photocopies and transcripts of some of those newspaper clippings are included.)

scopecontent.p: Dr. Riggs papers include newspaper clippings, obituaries and correspondence. Subjects include Oswego Normal School, Hall of Fame nomination of Dr. Edward Austin Sheldon and world tour correspondence.

scopecontent.p: 2-page handwritten list of 21 names. 17 incoming and outgoing letters between Dr. Riggs and many of the names on the aforementioned list concerning the nomination of Dr. Edward Austin Sheldon to the Hall of Fame at New York University. Correspondents include William C. Bagley (Columbia University), Robert A. Downey, Frank Pierrepont Graves, Dr. Monroe (Columbia University), Ned H. Dearborn (New York University), J. A. Pitman (President, State Teachers College at Salem, Massachusetts), Dr. Robert Underwood Johnson, D. B. Waldo (Western State Teachers College, Kalamazoo, Michigan), Charles H. Judd (University of Chicago), Payson Smith (Commissioner of Education, Boston, Massachusetts), J. W. Crabtree (National Education Association), and H.L. Smith (Dean, Indiana University).
